Chess Team Wins By 5- 1 Score;
To Meet Poly
Next
On December 21-22, 1936, the Johns
Hopkins chess beam played and defeated decisively the experienced chess
team of the Engineer's Club of Baltimore. The score of the match was
5-1 in favor of the Jays.
The Hopkins number one man, Howard Skinner, president of the club,
Played his match on the twenty-first
in order to accommodate his opponent
and lost his match in a hard fought
Bet. The other members of the Hopkins team, in order of their playing,
were Chicelli, Levie, Gray, Taragin,
and Diskin.
These boys won their
Matches in fine order, handing the Engineers' Club "one of the worst lickirigs it has ever suffered."
The next match will be a double
event In W1111,11 LWU LetILMO from Hop
kins will participate. During the first
Week of February a team from Hopkins will play the chess team of the
Baltimore Polytechnic High School.

gestions." Each Senior is requested

For Engineers
An oft-discussed subject these days
is the value of a "liberal education"
as an adjunct to the scientific studies
of the engineering student. Many
words have been bandied back and
forth, to little avail.
Perhaps the latest of the discussions of the matter occurred several
days ago at a meeting of the S.P.E.E.
In New York. President H. S. Rogers
of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute
and Dean H. Diedrichs of the College
of Engineering of Cornell University
unequivocally declared that the subjects classed as -'humanities" must
not be included in an engineering
Course.

The usual four-year course, they
claimed, is much too short to include
the study of non-engineering subjects. The education of an engineer
must provide for his amassing as

born to him on Christmas Day, be
rendered to the Great White Sahib.
"Illustrious Highness," began Press,
I could have danced for joy, "that my
humble gift to one so high in Allah's
esteem should find favorable reception pleases me more than these poor
words can convey. My heart, 0 my
Father, is a very temple of Joy."
"You have spoken well, my son,"
said Uncle Humphrey in a slow lofty
voice "May Allah look upon .you and
your issue with favor."
Then he turned and passed from
the hall out to the street.
We were still quietly celebrating
our success with speeches and toasts,
when the door was violently flung
open by Press. The extreme state of
my legs made it necessary to reduce
their burden, Uncle Humphrey too, I
noticed, was sitting down.
"Do you know what you and your
damn foolishness has done?" he
roared. "Well, you fixed me with Deborah. She thought you were a real
Indian and was so much impressed
that she said 'Yes'". And with an
awkward caper he dashed out into the
night shouting and yelling.
"You see," said Uncle Humphrey,
"that is the right way to celebrate the
holidays. Let's have another drink."

with the answer to society's need
that the large number of qualified
youth, whose lack of finances keeps
them from doing so, be enabled to
"equip themselves through adequate
education for the leadersnip and service necessary for the advancement of
the general welfare of the United
States."
The revised draft of American Youth
Act, which will be introduced into
Congress this month, provides, in
part, for students as follows:
The
Administration
(National
Youth Administration) shall establish a system of academic work projects to be conducted in or near all
colleges or other institutions of higher learning . . . Part time employment on such projects shall be open
to all young persons who are officially
enrolled for a course of study in any
institution of higher learning . . . and
who would be unable without financial
aid to continue in such course of
study. Regular wages shall be paid for
work done on such projects . . . In no
event shall work on such projects be
compensated at less than fifty cents
per hour.
Even in so brief and unsatisfactory
an article as this, it is fairly clear
that here is a piece of legislation that
is adequate for the needs of American
youth. Here is an act that, written
by youth, providing for youth, calls
for the full support of each of us.

An interesting and enlightening discussion of controversial topics was
broadcast by Northwestern University faculty members and students
last Monday. It was a timely seminar
on "Is Fascism coming to America."
Two weeks ago the same group discussed the question, "Should University faculty members enter politics."
Upon hearing from many listeners on
this subject, the body decided to the
affirmative.
This Monday at 10.30 over station
WCAO, "Will America enter the next
war," will be analyzed and debated.
Its really worth while to listen in.

Jay Representatives Split Two
Matches played Over
Holidays
Over the Christmas holidays the
Jay handballers played two of their
scheduled games against Long Island
University and Brooklyn College in
New York City. They defeated the
Long Island aggregation 4-3, while
they lost to Brooklyn by the score
of 7-0.
On December 21, the Hopkins
men met the Islanders on their single
wall court.
Dick Pasternak and
Milt Alperstein won their singles
matches but it was only after the two
doubles teams came through and won
their games that the meet was cinched. Dick Pasternak played exceptionally good handball in both his
matches.
The Baltimore wallmen lost to
Brooklyn on their single wall courts
the afternoon before Christmas.

meets:

M. Alperstein, J.H.U. defeated T. Bernet, 15-10, 15-11.

On December 21-22, 1936, the Johns
Hopkins chess beam played and defeated decisively the experienced chess
team of the Engineer's Club of Baltimore. The score of the match was
5-1 in favor of the Jays.
The Hopkins number one man, Howard Skinner, president of the club,
Played his match on the twenty-first
in order to accommodate his opponent
and lost his match in a hard fought
Bet. The other members of the Hopkins team, in order of their playing,
were Chicelli, Levie, Gray, Taragin,
and Diskin.
These boys won their
Matches in fine order, handing the Engineers' Club "one of the worst lickirigs it has ever suffered."

event In W1111,11 LWU LetILMO from Hop
kins will participate. During the first
Week of February a team from Hopkins will play the chess team of the

An oft-discussed subject these days
is the value of a "liberal education"
as an adjunct to the scientific studies
of the engineering student. Many
words have been bandied back and
forth, to little avail.
Perhaps the latest of the discussions of the matter occurred several
days ago at a meeting of the S.P.E.E.
In New York. President H. S. Rogers
of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute
and Dean H. Diedrichs of the College
of Engineering of Cornell University
unequivocally declared that the subjects classed as -'humanities" must
not be included in an engineering
Course.

The usual four-year course, they
claimed, is much too short to include
the study of non-engineering subjects. The education of an engineer
must provide for his amassing as

By his side again, I reported that
The Chosen One humbly wished his
profound appreciation for the gifts
born to him on Christmas Day, be
rendered to the Great White Sahib.
"Illustrious Highness," began Press,
I could have danced for joy, "that my
humble gift to one so high in Allah's
esteem should find favorable reception pleases me more than these poor
words can convey. My heart, 0 my
Father, is a very temple of Joy."
"You have spoken well, my son,"
said Uncle Humphrey in a slow lofty
voice "May Allah look upon .you and
your issue with favor."
Then he turned and passed from
the hall out to the street.
We were still quietly celebrating
our success with speeches and toasts,
when the door was violently flung
open by Press. The extreme state of
my legs made it necessary to reduce
their burden, Uncle Humphrey too, I
noticed, was sitting down.
"Do you know what you and your
damn foolishness has done?" he
roared. "Well, you fixed me with Deborah. She thought you were a real
Indian and was so much impressed
that she said 'Yes'". And with an
awkward caper he dashed out into the
night shouting and yelling.
"You see," said Uncle Humphrey,
"that is the right way to celebrate the
holidays. Let's have another drink."

who are "unemployed and to whom

for similar work," our essential concern is with the provision for students,
with the answer to society's need
that the large number of qualified
youth, whose lack of finances keeps
them from doing so, be enabled to
"equip themselves through adequate
education for the leadersnip and service necessary for the advancement of
the general welfare of the United
States."
The revised draft of American Youth
Act, which will be introduced into
Congress this month, provides, in
part, for students as follows:
The
Administration
(National
Youth Administration) shall establish a system of academic work projects to be conducted in or near all
colleges or other institutions of higher learning . . . Part time employment on such projects shall be open
to all young persons who are officially
enrolled for a course of study in any
institution of higher learning . . . and
who would be unable without financial
aid to continue in such course of
study. Regular wages shall be paid for
work done on such projects . . . In no
event shall work on such projects be
compensated at less than fifty cents
per hour.
Even in so brief and unsatisfactory
an article as this, it is fairly clear
that here is a piece of legislation that
is adequate for the needs of American
youth. Here is an act that, written
by youth, providing for youth, calls
for the full support of each of us.

preacher who protested the use of

a new-born babe, and the inscription
on it read, "Does your mother know
you're out?"

An interesting and enlightening discussion of controversial topics was
broadcast by Northwestern University faculty members and students
last Monday. It was a timely seminar
on "Is Fascism coming to America."
Two weeks ago the same group discussed the question, "Should University faculty members enter politics."
Upon hearing from many listeners on
this subject, the body decided to the
affirmative.
This Monday at 10.30 over station
WCAO, "Will America enter the next
war," will be analyzed and debated.
Its really worth while to listen in.

Under the practiced eye of Ed
Lotz, weekly boxing drills will be
held at the gymnasium. Starting
today practices will be scheduled
for 4 o'clock. All those eager to
develop their boxing potentialties
or anxious to learn something of
the art of fisticuffs are urged to
turn out.
Should enough be manifested, it
will be arranged to have bi-weekly
instruction in ring-craft. All necessary equipment is supplied by the
Athletic Department.

Jay Representatives Split Two
Matches played Over
Holidays
Over the Christmas holidays the
Jay handballers played two of their
scheduled games against Long Island
University and Brooklyn College in
New York City. They defeated the
Long Island aggregation 4-3, while
they lost to Brooklyn by the score
of 7-0.
On December 21, the Hopkins
men met the Islanders on their single
wall court.
Dick Pasternak and
Milt Alperstein won their singles
matches but it was only after the two
doubles teams came through and won
their games that the meet was cinched. Dick Pasternak played exceptionally good handball in both his
matches.
The Baltimore wallmen lost to
Brooklyn on their single wall courts
the afternoon before Christmas.
The following is a summary of the
meets:
Long Island vs. Johns Hopkins
Singles
J. Fererra, L.I.U. defeated I. Milberg,
6-15, 15-18, 15-13.
R. Pasternak, J.H.U. defeated J. Bernstein, 11-15, 15-9, 15-8.
S. Sanders, L.I.U. defeated N. Finkelstein, 11-15, 15-11, 15-1.
M. Alperstein, J.H.U. defeated T. Bernet, 15-10, 15-11.
